    Mesh networking: A guide to using free and open-source software with common hardware

    11 minute read

    Carlos Gomes

    I’m a scientist, psychologist, math modeler, programmer, mtg player, free knowledge supporter, sbc fanatic, and electronics hobbyist.

    • Brazil
    • Main e-mail
    • https://cgomesu.com

    Changelog

    Nov 25th, 2020: Publication of the original version

    Introduction

    In this tutorial, we will learn how to create a mesh network using OpenWrt and the layer-2 implementation of the Better Approach to Mobile Adhoc Networking, called batman-adv. All the software mentioned here is free and open-source, as opposed to commercial alternatives (UniFi Mesh or Google’s Nest Wifi).

    Of course, this is not meant to be an exhaustive presentation of any of the topics covered here. If you have suggestions on how to improve this guide, feel free to get in touch with me. I’m always eager to learn new things. Also, don’t hesitate to contact me if you just want to share your own mesh projects or bounce a few ideas. Different perspectives give an opportunity to learn, grow, and create.

    top

    Why am I writing this guide?

    Even though the concept of mesh networking has been around for quite some time now (REF), the documentation of its implementation is still scarce/nichey, proprietary, or outdated. I don’t feel qualified to speculate on why this is so but I find it odd because many of the radio devices found in popular wireless routers (REF) actually support mesh networking–but the original firmware rarely supports it.

    My intention with this tutorial is to help closing the gap between concept and implementation of mesh networking using up-to-date software that anyone can download and install on cheap, commonly available hardware. The content is partially based on my own experience and builds upon the work of other, much more talented individuals who shared their knowledge on the web. More specifically, the content is influenced by the following:

    • Brian Innes workshop about using Raspberry Pis to create a mesh network for sharing sensor data wirelessly (Github repo)
    • Maintaners of the OpenWRT documentation and the B.A.T.M.A.N. wiki
    • Multiple users from the OpenWrt forum who shared their opinions over the years. To name a few, the users slh, jeff, mcarni, oavaldezi, and many others. Thanks for keeping the posts public.

    top

    Objectives

    1. Get familiar with /etc/config/ files in OpenWrt devices (namely, wireless, network, dhcp, firewall) and how to edit them directly from the terminal using vi.
    2. Learn how to configure OpenWrt devices to play one of three possible roles in the network: (a) mesh node, (b) mesh + bridge node, or (c) mesh + gateway node.
    3. Install and configure batman-adv on an OpenWrt device using the opkg package manager.
    4. Learn how to use batctl to test, debug, and monitor connectivity within the mesh.
    5. Add encryption to the mesh network with the package wpad-mesh-openssl.
    6. Use VLANs to create default, iot, and guest networks within the mesh using batman-adv.

    top

    Outline

    From this point forward, the article is divided into three main parts:

    1. Concepts: Brief introduction to just enough network concepts (e.g., bridges, gateways) to allow the implementation of simple mesh networks.
    2. Hardware: Optional. A few notes about the hardware used in the examples and recommendations for those who are planning on buying new/used devices for their mesh project.
    3. Implementation: Step-by-step procedure to configure mesh nodes, bridges, and gateways. It goes from flashing OpenWrt to configuring VLANs with batman-adv. You probably came here for this part.

    top

    Hardware

    Unless otherwise specified, all mesh nodes used in the various implementations had the following hardware and OS versions:

    • Device: TP-Link WR-1043ND v1.8
    • Architecture: Atheros AR9132 rev 2
    • Firmware version: OpenWrt 19.07.4 r11208-ce6496d796
    • Kernel version: 4.14.195

    This was mainly a matter of convenience–I had a few lying around and they are very, very cheap–and because the examples in the OpenWrt documentation often refer to them as well, so the community support is good.

    However, the general ideas presented here should apply to any wireless device that meets the following criteria:

    1. Compatible with the latest OpenWRT version. Refer to their Hardware List;
    2. Supports the mesh point mode of operation. If you already have OpenWrt installed on a wireless device, you can type iw list and search for mesh point under Supported interface modes, or simply check if the following command outputs something:
    iw list | grep mesh

    Now, if you’re looking for devices to buy and experiment on, my suggestion is to look for dual-band wireless routers to allow a better segmentation of the wireless networks. If you can afford spending more for a mesh node, look for tri-band devices. Netgear and Linksys have solid options that are compatible with OpenWrt. For example, the Linksys WRT1900AC (v1/v2) dual-band wireless router would make for a good mesh node:

    Alternatively, you can run OpenWrt with a virtual machine or as a docker container. For single-board computer fans like me, you can run OpenWrt with most of them and then use a combination of on-board wireless and USB adapter to create a powerful mesh node. ClearFog boards with one or two mini PCIe wireless cards would make very good candidates for such a project, for example:

    Of course, you can install OpenWrt on bare metal x86-64 machines (e.g., standard PC or server running Intel/AMD), which will give you lots of options to put together an impressive mesh device. However, if you just want your work/home laptops/PCs to be part of the mesh (i.e., become a mesh node), there are better alternatives than installing OpenWrt as its OS. Check the section about nodes with other Linux distros, and for solutions based on virtualization, check the OpenWrt documentation.

    All that said, most home users will be just fine with a cheapo, used, old, single-band router. For a brand reference, TP-Link has good and affordable devices that can be used in a mesh networking project without issues. If you’re new to this, start from here (small, simple) and think about efficiency over power. You don’t need to drive a Lamborghini to get a snack at the grocery store.

    top

    Planning

    Install OpenWrt and configure it

    • Ref to installation notes
    • Hardening SSH access with key-based authentication: https://openwrt.org/docs/guide-user/security/dropbear.public-key.auth

    top

    Nodes with other Linux distros

    • general configuration for other devices running different linux distros to be able to join the mesh directly, isntead of depending on a bridged WAP access.

    top

    Final remarks

    Other similar mesh solutions

    If you found this guide overwhelming but you’re still curious about mesh networking, take a look at the following alternatives (in alphabetical order):

    • Commotion Wireless
    • LibreMesh

    They have pre-configured images that will work “out of the box” with compatible devices. You might find instructive to start playing around with their software first and once comfortable, build your own configuration from a default (or customized from the source) OpenWrt image.

    top

    EOF

    (For reference, you can run a mesh network with something as cheap and small as an ESP32. So, access to mesh-capable hardware is not the issue.)

    As usual, this is not meant to be an exhaustive presentation of any of the topics covered here. If you spot an error or have a suggestion, feel free to get in touch with me.

    The goal is to cover a few concepts about wireless networking and focus on the implementation of a mesh in a couple of network topologies commonly found in homes and small offices.

    Such a presentation could then be used as a template for more advanced implementations of a mesh network. While researching, I found outdated information and the good content is often times spread across multiple forum posts. This motivated me to write a simple guide for anyone who wants to experiment building their own mesh without relying on commercial solutions.

    and configurations for network topologies commonly found in homes and small offices

    to provide a template for more advanced implementations of a mesh network. While researching, I found outdated information and the good content is often times spread across multiple forum posts. This motivated me to write a simple guide for anyone who wants to experiment building their own mesh without relying on commercial solutions.

    If you want to dive deep into the features and configurations, read the actual docs:

    The goal is to cover a few basic configurations for common network topologies to provide a template for more advanced implementations of a mesh network. While researching, I found outdated information and the good content is often times spread across multiple forum posts. This motivated me to write a simple guide for anyone who wants to experiment building their own mesh without relying on commercial solutions.
